info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 39.
First game of Season 21.  New title graphics.

(1, 1).clue: Let's all flock to read Psalm 95, in which humans are compared to these animals

(2, 1).clue: The rap on him is he's sometimes "Puffy"

(3, 1).clue: In the 1980s this city passed Chicago as the USA's second most populous

(4, 1).clue: "Ask any mermaid you happen to see, 'What's the best tuna?'", this brand

(5, 1).clue: Many people have become familiar with "Shape", "Ski" & "Savoy", which are these, in doctors' waiting rooms

(6, 1).clue: In 2003, Roy E. Disney left it after being on it since 1967

(1, 2).clue: Some say the screech owl in the King James Bible is Lilith, the name given his legendary first wife

(3, 2).clue: This London borough is the G in GMT, squire

(4, 2).clue: A fast food chain: "If it doesn't get all over the place, it doesn't belong in your face"

(5, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the Briefing Room at the White House.)  The White House briefing room floor covers a swimming pool that was installed for this man in 1933

(6, 2).clue: It's where Bart Simpson is often found in the opening of "The Simpsons"

(1, 3).clue: Hagar, carrying this man's baby, fled into the desert after harsh treatment from his wife

(2, 3).clue: He won an Oscar for "The Untouchables"

(3, 3).clue: Thomas Alsgaard won the 15-kilometer cross-country ski event at the 1998 Winter Olympics in this Japanese city

(4, 3).clue: "Pardon me, but do you have any" of this fancy mustard?

(5, 3).clue: The Titanic has 3 rooms for this--only men were allowed there, as women weren't supposed to do it in public

(6, 3).clue: At this time we'd like to do this for our first-class passengers & those traveling with small children

(1, 4).clue: According to this Old Testament book, this "swords into plowshares" prophet walked naked for 3 years

(3, 4).clue: The Dalai Lama's former residence, the Potala Palace, overlooks this city

(4, 4).clue: "Kiss a little longer" with this gum

(5, 4).clue: Officially released in 1975, much-bootlegged tapes of Dylan & The Band were named for this space

(6, 4).clue: A structural material named for its small wood fragments pressed together & bonded

(1, 5).clue: In Genesis, Joseph is imprisoned after accusations by the wife of this Egyptian

(3, 5).clue: Founded by Ram Das, this city in Punjab state is home to the Golden Temple, the center of the Sikh faith

(4, 5).clue: The slogan of this Johnson & Johnson product was "Have you had your sprinkle today?"

(5, 5).clue: Decorating experts, & the film "The Big Lebowski", advise that the right one of these really ties a room together

(6, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reads from the Cirque du Soleil.)  When used by acrobats, this structure isn't called a seesaw, but this

(1, 1).clue: Toledo military academy class of 1910 grad who went on to become a dictator

(2, 1).clue: Nicole Kidman finds a photo book containing a postmortem image of her current housekeeper in this chiller

(3, 1).clue: After turning the key, it's the final action with which you start a Yamaha YZ426F 4-stroke motorcycle

(5, 1).clue: "And how should I begin?" Hmmm, T.S., why not with the alphabetically first country, whose Internet code is .af

(6, 1).clue: This U.S. state's name comes from an Aleut word meaning "Great Land"

(1, 2).clue: Mindon, as emperor of this country, set up a new capital in 1857 at Mandalay

(2, 2).clue: This actor played a medium hired to investigate the Everest of Haunted Houses in "Legend of Hell House"

(3, 2).clue: The Champlain & St. Lawrence Railroad opened in 1836 powered by this, but soon became Canada's first powered by steam

(5, 2).clue: "Do I dare disturb the universe?", maybe like this cosmic explosion theory first proposed in the 1920s

(6, 2).clue: (Jeff Probst, host of Survivor, reads the clue.)  This river got its name after a Spanish explorer reported that he had been attacked by female warriors there

(1, 3).clue: His 5 classics were canonized during the Han Dynasty

(2, 3).clue: David's haunted by the decomposing corpse of his friend Jack after being attacked on the British moors in this 1981 film

(3, 3).clue: The vessel seen here, the type of missile it carries or a much more low-tech weapon

(5, 3).clue: "So how should I presume?" Not with this argumentative fallacy attacking the person & not the facts

(6, 3).clue: This basic unit of measure of electric current is named for a French physicist who studied voltage

(1, 4).clue: Edmund "Crouchback" founded this branch of the Plantagenets that didn't get on well with the Yorks

(2, 4).clue: In "The Gift" this Aussie actress plays a psychic who gets some much needed help from her former client

(3, 4).clue: The U.S. company Trek makes Lance Armstrong's bikes from a composite of this often-compounded element

(5, 4).clue: "In the room the women come and go talking of Michelangelo", but do they know this statue was the only 1 he signed?

(6, 4).clue: To increase a jet plane's thrust, turn on these that feed fuel into the hot exhaust gases

(1, 5).clue: In 1825, the Decembrists attempted a coup in this country--didn't work

(2, 5).clue: Rex Harrison is a curmudgeonly sea captain's ghost haunting Gene Tierney's cottage in this 1947 classic

(3, 5).clue: In 1980 you could haul brie in the Renault sold in the U.S. under this half-French name

(5, 5).clue: "Do I dare to eat a peach?", & if so, perhaps this kind that sounds like William Sydney Porter's alias

(6, 5).clue: There's a cathedral of Notre Dame in this large Belgian port city that's also known for its diamonds

(0, 0).clue: In 2002 the Library of Congress had William B. Jones, Jr. speak on this 1941-1971 comic book series in its collection
